title: How to build trust and grow as a product leader | Fareed Mosavat (Reforge, Slack, Instacart, Pixar)
key_insights: Product management skills can only be developed through real work with real customers and data - exercises and homework aren't sufficient
Career acceleration follows a loop: execute → generalize learnings → communicate effectively → scale opportunities
The transition from IC to manager often fails due to a 'death spiral' where managers keep the best work for themselves
Successful PMs understand their work 'two stack levels up and down' - knowing their boss's boss's priorities and technical implementation details
Sponsorship (someone giving you bigger opportunities) is more impactful than mentorship for career growth
Product leaders must own business outcomes and marshal resources, not just optimize with what they're given
There are four types of product work: feature work, growth work, product-market fit expansion, and scaling work
Senior operators are increasingly choosing portfolio careers over traditional full-time roles
topics_discussed: Why product management is inherently difficult to learn
The learning loop for product managers
Building trust and finding sponsors in organizations
The Product Leader Canyon - transitioning from IC to manager
Manager death spiral and how to avoid it
Four types of product work framework
Career inflection points and growth moments
Alternative career paths: advisors and fractional executives
Pixar experience and creative-technical problem solving
memorable_quotes: You can't do homework. You can't do exercises. You can't do fake stuff. You have to work on real products at real companies with real customers, with real data to get better at product management.
At the core is you have to actually execute and deliver great products, and you have to do it over, and over, and over again.
What's the least amount of work I could do to make this thing as good as possible? versus How do I do as much work as possible to make sure it's great?
frameworks_mentioned: Four types of product work (feature, growth, product-market fit expansion, scaling)
Learning acceleration loop (execute → generalize → communicate → scale)
Two stack levels up/down curiosity framework
recommended_for: Product managers looking to advance their careers
Anyone interested in growth and product strategy
summary: Fareed Mosavat shares tactical frameworks for accelerating product management careers, focusing on the execution-learning loop and the critical transition from individual contributor to leader. He provides specific strategies for building trust, finding sponsors, and avoiding common pitfalls while exploring emerging alternative career paths in tech.
